# Automotive industry in Russia

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Lada_Vesta_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-
Lada_Vesta_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lada_Vesta_\(cropped\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lada_Vesta_\(cropped\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Lada Vesta](/wiki/Lada_Vesta "Lada Vesta") went into production in 2015

**Automotive production** is a significant industry in [Russia](/wiki/Russia
"Russia"), directly employing around 600,000 people or 1% of the country's
total workforce. Russia produced 1,303,989 vehicles in 2016, ranking 16th
among car-producing nations in 2016, and accounting for 1.4% of the worldwide
production.[1] The main local brands are light vehicle producers
[AvtoVAZ](/wiki/AvtoVAZ "AvtoVAZ") and [GAZ](/wiki/GAZ "GAZ"), while
[KamAZ](/wiki/Kamaz "Kamaz") is the leading heavy vehicle producer. Eleven
foreign carmakers have production operations or are constructing their plants
in Russia.

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Automotive_industry_in_Russia&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

### Early
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Automotive_industry_in_Russia&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Early history")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/%D0%A0%D1%83%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BB%D1%8C.jpg/220px-%D0%A0%D1%83%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BB%D1%8C.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%A0%D1%83%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BB%D1%8C.jpg)

"Enlarge")

Yakovlev & Freze (1896)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B2%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D1%8D%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%81_%D0%98.%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0.jpg/220px-%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B2%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D1%8D%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%81_%D0%98.%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B2%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D1%8D%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%81_%D0%98.%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B2%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D1%8D%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%81_%D0%98.%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0.jpg
"Enlarge")

Hippolyte Romanov's electric bus in [Gatchina](/wiki/Gatchina "Gatchina")

The [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") had a long history
of progress in the development of [machinery](/wiki/Machine_\(mechanical\)
"Machine \(mechanical\)"). As early as in the eighteenth century [Ivan I.
Polzunov](/wiki/Ivan_Polzunov "Ivan Polzunov") constructed the first two-
cylinder [steam engine](/wiki/Steam_engine "Steam engine") in the world,[2]
while [Ivan P. Kulibin](/wiki/Ivan_Kulibin "Ivan Kulibin") created a [human-
powered vehicle](/wiki/Human-powered_transport "Human-powered transport") that
had a [flywheel](/wiki/Flywheel "Flywheel"), a [brake](/wiki/Brake "Brake"), a
[gearbox](/wiki/Gearbox "Gearbox"), and [roller bearings](/wiki/Rolling-
element_bearing "Rolling-element bearing").[3] One of the world's first
[tracked vehicles](/wiki/Tracked_vehicle "Tracked vehicle") was invented by
[Fyodor A. Blinov](/wiki/Fyodor_Blinov "Fyodor Blinov") in 1877.[4] In 1896,
the Yakovlev engine factory and the Freze carriage-manufacturing workshop
manufactured the first Russian petrol-engine automobile, the Yakovlev &
Freze.[5]

The turn of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries was marked by the invention
of the earliest Russian [electrocar](/wiki/Electrocar "Electrocar"), nicknamed
the “[Cuckoo](/wiki/Cuckoo "Cuckoo")”, which was created by the engineer
[Hippolyte V. Romanov](/wiki/Hippolyte_Romanov "Hippolyte Romanov") in 1899.
Romanov also constructed a battery-electric omnibus.[6] In the years preceding
the 1917 [October Revolution](/wiki/October_Revolution "October Revolution"),
Russia produced a growing number of [Russo-Balt](/wiki/Russo-Balt "Russo-
Balt"), [Puzyryov](/w/index.php?title=Puzyryov&action=edit&redlink=1 "Puzyryov
\(page does not exist\)"),
[Lessner](/w/index.php?title=Lessner&action=edit&redlink=1 "Lessner \(page
does not exist\)"), and other vehicles, held its first motor show in 1907[7]
and had car enthusiasts who successfully participated in international motor
racing. A Russo-Balt car placed 9th in the [Monte Carlo
Rally](/wiki/Monte_Carlo_Rally "Monte Carlo Rally") of 1912, despite the
extreme winter conditions that threatened the lives of the driver and [riding
mechanic](/wiki/Riding_mechanic "Riding mechanic") on their way from [Saint
Petersburg](/wiki/Saint_Petersburg "Saint Petersburg"),[8] 2nd in the San
Sebastián Rally and covered more than 15,000 km in [Western
Europe](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western Europe") and [Northern
Africa](/wiki/Northern_Africa "Northern Africa") in 1913. The driver of the
car, Andrei P. Nagel, was personally awarded by Emperor [Nicholas
II](/wiki/Nicholas_II "Nicholas II") for increasing the prestige of the
domestic car brand.[9]

By 1915, about 1,000 motor vehicles had been built in Russia.[10] Imported
vehicles vastly exceeded domestic production, with the latter accounting for
less than 10% of total stock by 1914.[10]

In February 1916 the Tsarist government allocated funds for the construction
of six automotive plants: AMO in Moscow, Russo-Balt in the village of
[Fili](/wiki/Fili_\(Moscow\) "Fili \(Moscow\)"), the State Plant of Military
Self-Propelled Vehicles (KZVS) in [Mytishchi](/wiki/Mytishchi "Mytishchi"),
Russian Renault in [Rybinsk](/wiki/Rybinsk "Rybinsk"), Aksai in [Nakhichevan-
on-Don](/wiki/Nakhichevan-on-Don "Nakhichevan-on-Don"), and Lebedev in
[Yaroslavl](/wiki/Yaroslavl "Yaroslavl"). None of the plants were completed
before the October Revolution.[11]

### Soviet
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Automotive_industry_in_Russia&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Soviet era")]

See also: [Automobile industry of the Soviet
Union](/wiki/Automobile_industry_of_the_Soviet_Union "Automobile industry of
the Soviet Union")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/RIAN_archive_878967_AvtoVAZ-
_Volga_automaking_plant_in_Togliatti%2C_the_Samara_Region.jpg/220px-
RIAN_archive_878967_AvtoVAZ-
_Volga_automaking_plant_in_Togliatti%2C_the_Samara_Region.jpg)](/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_878967_AvtoVAZ-
_Volga_automaking_plant_in_Togliatti,_the_Samara_Region.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_878967_AvtoVAZ-
_Volga_automaking_plant_in_Togliatti,_the_Samara_Region.jpg "Enlarge")

The [AvtoVAZ](/wiki/AvtoVAZ "AvtoVAZ") assembly line in 1969

After the 1917 [October Revolution](/wiki/October_Revolution "October
Revolution"), Russo-Balt was nationalised on August 15, 1918, and renamed to
[Prombron](/wiki/Prombron "Prombron") by the new leadership. It continued the
production of Russo-Balt cars and launched a new model on October 8, 1922,
while AMO built FIAT 15 Ter trucks under licence and released a more modern
FIAT-derived truck developed by a team of AMO designers, the AMO-F-15. About
6,000–6,500 F-15s were built in the years 1924–1931.[12][13]

In 1927, engineers from the [Scientific Automobile & Motor
Institute](/wiki/Central_Scientific_Research_Automobile_and_Automotive_Engines_Institute
"Central Scientific Research Automobile and Automotive Engines Institute")
(NAMI) created the first original Soviet car NAMI-I, which was produced in
small numbers by the Spartak State Automobile Factory in Moscow, between 1927
and 1931.[14] In 1929, due to a rapidly growing demand for automobiles and in
cooperation with its trade partner, the [Ford Motor
Company](/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company "Ford Motor Company"), the [Supreme Soviet
of the National Economy](/wiki/Supreme_Soviet_of_the_National_Economy "Supreme
Soviet of the National Economy") established [GAZ](/wiki/GAZ "GAZ").[15][16] A
year later, a second automobile plant was founded in [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow
"Moscow"), which would become a major Soviet car maker after [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and earn nationwide fame under the name
[Moskvitch](/wiki/Moskvitch "Moskvitch").

The beginning of the 1960s saw the release of the [Moskvitch
408](/wiki/Moskvitch_408 "Moskvitch 408"), intended to be an [economy
car](/wiki/Economy_car "Economy car") that would spread the use of cars among
the population.[17] Other manufacturers such as MZMA, GAZ and ZAZ were
offering a variety of cars intended for the mass market. The Soviet government
opted to build an even larger car manufacturing plant that would produce a
people's car and help to meet the demand for personal transport.[18] For
reasons of cost-efficiency, it was decided to produce the car on the basis of
an existing, modern foreign model. After considering several options, the
[Fiat 124](/wiki/FIAT_124 "FIAT 124") was chosen because of its simple and
sturdy design, being easy to manufacture and repair.

The plant was built in just 4 years (1966–1970) in the small town of
[Stavropol
Volzhsky](/w/index.php?title=Stavropol_Volzhsky&action=edit&redlink=1
"Stavropol Volzhsky \(page does not exist\)"), which later grew to a
population of more than half a million and was renamed
[Togliatti](/wiki/Tolyatti "Tolyatti") to commemorate [Palmiro
Togliatti](/wiki/Palmiro_Togliatti "Palmiro Togliatti").[18][19] At the same
time, the [Izhmash](/wiki/Lada_Izhevsk "Lada Izhevsk") car plant was
established in the city of [Izhevsk](/wiki/Izhevsk "Izhevsk") as part of the
Izhevsk Mechanical Plant, with the initiative coming from the [Minister of
Defence](/wiki/Dmitriy_Ustinov "Dmitriy Ustinov")[20] and in order to increase
the overall production of cars in the Soviet Union. It produced
[Moskvitchs](/wiki/Moskvitch "Moskvitch") and Moskvitch-based [_kombi_
hatchbacks](/wiki/Izh_2125 "Izh 2125"). [KaMAZ](/wiki/KaMAZ "KaMAZ"), Europe's
largest heavy truck plant, was built in [Naberezhnye
Chelny](/wiki/Naberezhnye_Chelny "Naberezhnye Chelny"), while [GAZ](/wiki/GAZ
"GAZ"), [ZIL](/wiki/ZiL "ZiL"), [UralAZ](/wiki/Ural_Automotive_Plant "Ural
Automotive Plant"), [KrAZ](/wiki/KrAZ "KrAZ"),
[MAZ](/wiki/Minsk_Automobile_Plant "Minsk Automobile Plant"),
[BelAZ](/wiki/BelAZ "BelAZ"), and plants continued to produce other types of
trucks.

By the early 1980s, Soviet automobile industry consisted of several main
plants, which produced vehicles for various market segments. In late 1987, the
industry produced 2 million cars, satisfying 45% of the domestic demand.[21]

### Post-Soviet
adjustments[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Automotive_industry_in_Russia&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Post-Soviet adjustments")]

In the early 1990s the Russian car market expanded dramatically, largely due
to a drastic cut on import duties, so that by 1993 foreign-made imported cars
made up 49% of all sales.[22] At the same time, Russian automakers were
integrated into a [market economy](/wiki/Market_economy "Market economy") and
immediately hit by a crisis due to the loss of financial support, economic
turmoil, criminal activities[23][24][25] and stiffer competition in the
domestic market during the 1990s.

The main domestic manufacturers in the early 1990s were
[AvtoVAZ](/wiki/AvtoVAZ "AvtoVAZ"), [AZLK](/wiki/AZLK "AZLK"),
[IzhAvto](/wiki/IzhAvto "IzhAvto"), [GAZ](/wiki/GAZ "GAZ") and [UAZ](/wiki/UAZ
"UAZ").[26] Some of them, like AvtoVAZ, turned to cooperation with other
companies (such as [GM-AvtoVAZ](/wiki/GM-AvtoVAZ "GM-AvtoVAZ")) in order to
obtain substantial capital investment and overcome the crisis.[27]

By 1993, total output was down 14% compared to 1990 levels. Lada's declining
sales during the 1990s, and toughening [European Union](/wiki/European_Union
"European Union") emissions requirements, saw exports to [Western
Europe](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western Europe") discontinued by the end of the
decade. Lada had enjoyed particularly strong sales in Britain, peaking at more
than 30,000 sales a year in the late 1980s, but had failed to remain
competitive with other budget brands over the subsequent few years.

850,000 cars were sold in 1996.[28] As demand kept rising, local brands
continued to be affected by a reputation for poor manufacturing quality. In
was estimated in 1996 that a newly bought AvtoVAZ car needed $1-2,000 worth of
repairs to bring it to a comfortable level of safety.[28]

The [1998 Russian financial crisis](/wiki/1998_Russian_financial_crisis "1998
Russian financial crisis") affected the industry, as car manufacturers stopped
using imported components because of higher import prices. Nevertheless, the
industry quickly recovered in subsequent years.[29]

In 1997, car production increased by 13.2% in comparison with 1996 and
achieved 981,000. AvtoVAZ and UAZ extended their output by 8.8 and 52 percent
respectively, whereas KamAZ doubled it. The overall truck production in Russia
increased by 7 percent, reaching 148,000 in 1997[30] and 184,000 in 2000.[31]
The overall production of cars rose from about 800,000 in 1993 to more than
1.16 million in 2000,[32] or 965,000[33] (969,235 according to
[OICA](/wiki/Organisation_Internationale_des_Constructeurs_d%27Automobiles
"Organisation Internationale des Constructeurs d'Automobiles")[34]) excluding
commercial vehicles.

Throughout the 1990s, the unavailability of dealer financing meant that cars
had to be purchased in cash.[22]

### 2000 to
2008[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Automotive_industry_in_Russia&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: 2000 to 2008")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%B9%D0%B5%D1%80_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0_%27%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0%27.jpg/220px-%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%B9%D0%B5%D1%80_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0_%27%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0%27.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%B9%D0%B5%D1%80_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0_%27%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0%27.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%B9%D0%B5%D1%80_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0_%27%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0%27.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Lada Samara](/wiki/Lada_Samara "Lada Samara") assembly line in 2005

In the early 2000s, the [Russian economy](/wiki/Economy_of_Russia "Economy of
Russia") recovered. Russian metal companies, having achieved significant
profits on foreign markets, sought to invest in Russia's automotive
sector.[35] [Siberian Aluminum](/wiki/Siberian_Aluminum "Siberian Aluminum")
initially bought [Pavlovo Bus Factory](/wiki/Pavlovo_Bus_Factory "Pavlovo Bus
Factory") and accumulated increasing ownership stakes in [GAZ](/wiki/GAZ
"GAZ"). At the same time, [Severstal](/wiki/Severstal "Severstal") gained
control of [UAZ](/wiki/UAZ "UAZ").[35]

In 2001 Ford became the first western manufacturer to establish its own
assembly plant in Russia, investing $150 million in their
[Vsevolozhsk](/wiki/Vsevolozhsk "Vsevolozhsk") factory, manufacturing the
[Ford Focus](/wiki/Ford_Focus "Ford Focus"), which briefly became the best-
selling foreign-branded car in Russia.[36]

In 2003 Russian manufacturers still accounted for over 90% of car production
in Russia, either under their own brand or in partnership with a foreign
company. The six main automotive groups were [AvtoVAZ](/wiki/AvtoVAZ
"AvtoVAZ"), [SOK Group](/wiki/SOK_Group "SOK Group"), [Kamaz](/wiki/Kamaz
"Kamaz"), [RusPromAvto](/wiki/RusPromAvto "RusPromAvto"),
[SeverstalAvto](/wiki/SeverstalAvto "SeverstalAvto") and [AZLK](/wiki/AZLK
"AZLK").[37] Just 11,000 cars were locally assembled by foreign manufacturers
in 2002.[38]

Macroeconomic trends were strong and growing incomes of the population led to
a surging demand, and by 2005 the Russian car market was booming. In 2005,
1,446,525 new cars were sold, including 832,200 Russian models and 614,325
foreign ones.

During the first quarter of 2005, foreign-branded cars outsold local ones for
the first time in Russian history (including used imports).[36] Foreign
companies started to massively invest in production in Russia: the number of
foreign cars produced in the Russian Federation surged from 157,179 in 2005 to
456,500 in 2007.[39] To keep up with the competition, local brands launched
more modern-looking models, such as [Lada Kalina](/wiki/Lada_Kalina "Lada
Kalina").[36]

The value of the Russian market grew at a brisk pace: 14% in 2005, 36% in 2006
and 67% in 2007—making it the world's fastest growing automotive market by
2008.[40] Foreign companies started flocking to enter Russia in the 2000s,
seeing it as a local production location and export powerhouse. Russia's
labour, material and energy costs were only 1/6 compared to those in Western
Europe.[41][42]

To boost the market share of locally produced vehicles, the [Russian
government](/wiki/Government_of_Russia "Government of Russia") implemented
several [protectionist](/wiki/Protectionism "Protectionism") measures and
launched programs to attract foreign producers into the country. In late 2005,
the Russian leadership enacted legislation to create [special economic
zones](/wiki/Special_economic_zone "Special economic zone") (SEZ) with the aim
of encouraging investments by foreign automotive companies. The benefits of
operating in the special economic zones include tax allowances, exemption from
asset and land taxes and protection against changes in the tax regime. Some
regions also provide extensive support for large investors (over $100
million.) These include [Saint Petersburg](/wiki/Saint_Petersburg "Saint
Petersburg")/[Leningrad Oblast](/wiki/Leningrad_Oblast "Leningrad Oblast")
(Toyota, GM, Nissan) and [Kaluga Oblast](/wiki/Kaluga_Oblast "Kaluga Oblast")
(VW). Kaluga has been especially successful in attracting foreign companies,
as has been [Kaliningrad Oblast](/wiki/Kaliningrad_Oblast "Kaliningrad
Oblast").[40]

### Global financial
crisis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Automotive_industry_in_Russia&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Global financial crisis")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Putin_with_Avtovaz_employees_in_2007.jpg/220px-
Putin_with_Avtovaz_employees_in_2007.jpg)](/wiki/File:Putin_with_Avtovaz_employees_in_2007.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Putin_with_Avtovaz_employees_in_2007.jpg "Enlarge")

President [Vladimir Putin](/wiki/Vladimir_Putin "Vladimir Putin") meeting with
[AvtoVAZ](/wiki/AvtoVAZ "AvtoVAZ") employees in the company's factory in
[Tolyatti](/wiki/Tolyatti "Tolyatti").

Russia's automotive industry was hit hard by the [late 2000s
recession](/wiki/Late_2000s_recession "Late 2000s recession"). Production of
passenger cars dropped from 1,470,000 units in 2008 to just 597,000 units in
2009. Lorry production fell from 256,000 to 91,000 in the same period.[43]

In late 2008, the Russian government introduced protectionist measures, worth
$5 billion, to improve the situation in the industry. This included $2 billion
of [bailouts](/wiki/Bailout "Bailout") for troubled companies and $3 billion
of credits for buyers of Russian cars.[44] Prime minister [Vladimir
Putin](/wiki/Vladimir_Putin "Vladimir Putin") described the move as vital in
order to save jobs.[45] The tariffs for imported foreign cars and trucks were
increased to a minimum of 50% and go up to 100%. The tariffs are linked to the
engine size of the vehicle. The increased duties led to protests in Russian
cities, most notably in [Vladivostok](/wiki/Vladivostok "Vladivostok"), where
the importation of Japanese cars is an important sector of the city's
economy.[46] To compensate for the losses of the Vladivostok businesses, Prime
Minister Putin ordered the car manufacturing company
[Sollers](/wiki/Sollers_JSC "Sollers JSC") to move one of its factories from
[Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow") to Vladivostok. The move was completed in
2009, and the factory now employs about 700 locals. It was planned to produce
13,200 cars in Vladivostok in 2010.[47]

The most efficient anti-crisis measure executed by the Russian government was
the introduction of a [car scrappage scheme](/wiki/Car_scrappage_scheme "Car
scrappage scheme") in March 2010. Under the scheme, buyers of new cars could
receive a subsidy of up to 600,000 rubles (20,000 USD).[48] Sales of Russia's
largest carmaker [Avtovaz](/wiki/Avtovaz "Avtovaz") doubled in the second
quarter of 2010 as a result, and the company returned to profit.[49][50]

### Recent
developments[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Automotive_industry_in_Russia&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Recent developments")]

By the end of 2010, automotive production had returned to pre-crisis
levels.[51][52] Nine out of the ten most sold models in Russia in 2010 were
domestically produced, with Avtovaz's Lada models topping the list.[51] In the
first 7 months of 2010, sales of Lada cars increased by 60%, the Korean KIA
reported a jump of 101%, and Chevrolet's sales rose by 15%.[53]

In 2010, Russia was the world's 15th largest producer of cars. The Russian
automotive industry currently (as of 2010) accounts for about 2% of worldwide
car production.[54]

The market share of Russian-branded vehicles fell to 34% in 2010 and to 21% in
2012. At the same time, the market share of foreign-branded cars made in
Russia kept rising, reaching 45% in 2012.[55] Imported vehicles account for a
sizable portion of the Russian automotive market: in 2014 they made up 27% of
cars and 46% of trucks.[56]

The [2014 economic
crisis](/wiki/Russian_financial_crisis_\(2014%E2%80%932017\) "Russian
financial crisis \(2014–2017\)") led to a new fall in car sales and production
levels, and reduced forecasts for future growth.[57]

The number of cars on Russian roads reached 40,629,200 in 2016. Lada cars
accounted for 34.6% of the total,[58] down from 41.6% five years earlier.[59]
Almost half of those cars were over ten years old, and the single most popular
car model was still the classic [Lada Riva](/wiki/Lada_Riva "Lada Riva").[58]

##
Manufacturers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Automotive_industry_in_Russia&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Manufacturers")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Passenger_car_production_statistics_-
_Russia_1997_-_2015_%28OICA%29.png/220px-Passenger_car_production_statistics_-
_Russia_1997_-_2015_%28OICA%29.png)](/wiki/File:Passenger_car_production_statistics_-
_Russia_1997_-_2015_\(OICA\).png)

[](/wiki/File:Passenger_car_production_statistics_-
_Russia_1997_-_2015_\(OICA\).png "Enlarge")

Cars produced in Russia between 1997-2015

The Russian automotive industry can be divided into four types of companies:
local brand producers, foreign OEMs, joint ventures and Russian companies
producing foreign brands.[60] In 2008, there were 5,445 companies
manufacturing vehicles and related equipment in Russia. The volume of
production and sales amounted to 1,513 billion rubles.[43]

Cars with [diesel engines](/wiki/Diesel_engines "Diesel engines") are not
popular in Russia, accounting for just 7.6% of all sales as of 2015, compared
to half of the market in much of Western Europe.[61] There are 145,000
[natural gas vehicles](/wiki/Natural_gas_vehicles "Natural gas vehicles") in
Russia as of 2016, or 0.3% of all vehicles in the country.[62] The sale of
[leaded gasoline](/wiki/Leaded_gasoline "Leaded gasoline") was outlawed in
2003.[63]

### Domestic car
brands[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Automotive_industry_in_Russia&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Domestic car brands")]

The four most popular cars in Russia in 2009 were all AvtoVAZ models. The
economy car [Lada Priora](/wiki/Lada_Priora "Lada Priora") topped the list
with 84,779 sold units. [Lada Samara](/wiki/Lada_Samara "Lada Samara") was
second with 77,679 units sold in Russia, and the classic [Lada
2105/2107](/wiki/Lada_Riva "Lada Riva") was third with sales of 57,499. Lada
2105 was expected to considerably increase sales following the car scrappage
scheme launched in March 2010. The higher-end [Lada Kalina](/wiki/Lada_Kalina
"Lada Kalina") was the fourth most sold car in Russia in 2009, selling 52,499
units that year.[64]

In the light commercial vehicle sector, the [GAZelle](/wiki/GAZelle "GAZelle")
van, manufactured by [GAZ](/wiki/GAZ "GAZ") has been very popular, occupying a
market share of 49% in 2009 and selling 42,400 units. The
[Avtoperevozchik](/w/index.php?title=Avtoperevozchik&action=edit&redlink=1
"Avtoperevozchik \(page does not exist\)") magazine declared GAZelle as the
most successful vehicle of 2009 in the Russian automotive market.[65]

The largest company of Russia's automotive industry is [Avtovaz](/wiki/Avtovaz
"Avtovaz"), located in the city of [Tolyatti](/wiki/Tolyatti "Tolyatti"). It
currently employs more than 130,000 people, and its Lada models dominate the
Russian car market. Avtovaz models account for about 50% of Russia's total car
production.[48]

Russian car manufacturing companies are represented by two associations, ASM-
Holding (АСМ-холдинг) and the Association of Russian Automakers (Объединением
автопроизводителей России).[66]

### Foreign car
brands[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Automotive_industry_in_Russia&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Foreign car brands")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA_\(cropped\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA_\(cropped\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Hyundai Solaris](/wiki/Hyundai_Solaris "Hyundai Solaris"), the first foreign
car to top Russian sales chart

Russia's second largest car manufacturer is [Avtotor](/wiki/Avtotor
"Avtotor"), located in [Kaliningrad Oblast](/wiki/Kaliningrad_Oblast
"Kaliningrad Oblast"). Avtotor performs SKD, CKD or full-cycle assembly of
foreign models, such as [BMW](/wiki/BMW "BMW"), [Kia](/wiki/Kia_Motors "Kia
Motors"), and [General Motors](/wiki/General_Motors "General Motors")'
[Cadillac](/wiki/Cadillac "Cadillac") and [Chevrolet](/wiki/Chevrolet
"Chevrolet") vehicles. In 2009, Avtotor produced 60,000 cars and accounted for
10% of Russian car production.[48]

[Avtoframos](/wiki/Avtoframos "Avtoframos"), the third largest car
manufacturer, produced 49,500 cars in 2009. Its plant is located in the south-
east part of the city of Moscow. Avtoframos is a joint venture between
France's [Renault](/wiki/Renault "Renault") and the Moscow city
administration, but is majority owned by Renault.[48] The company manufactures
[Renault Logan](/wiki/Renault_Logan "Renault Logan") and [Renault
Sandero](/wiki/Renault_Sandero "Renault Sandero") models. The ratio of
Russian-made parts is 54%. The figure was expected to rise to 74% by 2012.[67]

The fourth and fifth largest carmakers in Russia are
[Volkswagen](/wiki/Volkswagen "Volkswagen") and [Ford](/wiki/Ford "Ford"),
respectively. In total, the five largest companies of the industry account for
80% of all cars made in Russia.[48] In 2016, [Hyundai
Solaris](/wiki/Hyundai_Solaris "Hyundai Solaris") became the first foreign-
branded car to be the best-selling vehicle in the country since sales
statistics began in 1970.[68]

### Commercial and heavy
vehicles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Automotive_industry_in_Russia&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Commercial and heavy vehicles")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Gorky_Automobile_Plant_in_Nizhniy_Novgorod_%2820%29.jpg/220px-
Gorky_Automobile_Plant_in_Nizhniy_Novgorod_%2820%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gorky_Automobile_Plant_in_Nizhniy_Novgorod_\(20\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gorky_Automobile_Plant_in_Nizhniy_Novgorod_\(20\).jpg "Enlarge")

The [GAZelle NEXT](/wiki/GAZelle_NEXT "GAZelle NEXT") van, produced by
[GAZ](/wiki/GAZ "GAZ"), is popular on the light commercial vehicle market

In the heavy vehicle sector, the largest company is the truckmaker
[KaMAZ](/wiki/KaMAZ "KaMAZ"). It is also one of the largest companies in the
whole Russian automotive industry. In 2010, KaMAZ sold a total of 32,293
trucks; 28,254 in Russia and 4,039 in foreign countries.[69]

Another very important company is [GAZ](/wiki/GAZ "GAZ"), which makes vans,
trucks and busses, among other products. Its most popular product is the
[GAZelle](/wiki/GAZelle "GAZelle") van, which has a market share of 49% in the
light commercial vehicle market. In 2009, the company launched an improved
version, called GAZelle Business.

In the bus sector, the [GAZ Group Bus Division](/wiki/GAZ_Group_Bus_Division
"GAZ Group Bus Division") occupied a market share of 77%. In 2009 it sold
6,169 buses in the small-class, 1,806 in the medium class and 1,156 in the
large class.[65]

Russia's largest tractor maker, and one of the largest machine building
companies in the world, is [Concern Tractor
Plants](/wiki/Concern_Tractor_Plants "Concern Tractor Plants"), located in
[Cheboksary](/wiki/Cheboksary "Cheboksary"). The company employs around 45,000
people.

### Short-lived
projects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Automotive_industry_in_Russia&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Short-lived projects")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Marussia_B2.jpg/220px-
Marussia_B2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Marussia_B2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Marussia_B2.jpg "Enlarge")

[Marussia](/wiki/Marussia "Marussia") B2

The _Marussia_ brand, produced by [Marussia Motors](/wiki/Marussia_Motors
"Marussia Motors"), became the first modern [sports car](/wiki/Sports_car
"Sports car") and the first [supercar](/wiki/Supercar "Supercar") produced in
Russia. The Marussia B1 was launched on 16 December 2008 in the New Manezh
Hall in Moscow. On 10 September 2010 the first Marussia Motors show room
opened in Moscow.[70] Marussia Motors was led by [Nikolay
Fomenko](/wiki/Nikolay_Fomenko "Nikolay Fomenko"), a notable Russian showman,
singer, actor and racer. His company acquired a 'significant stake' in the
[Virgin Racing](/wiki/Virgin_Racing "Virgin Racing") Formula One team, which
was renamed Marussia Virgin Racing from 2011.[71] This team is to become the
first ever Russian-owned team in [Formula One](/wiki/Formula_One "Formula
One"). Marussia Motors declared bankruptcy and ceased both support for their
F1 team[72] and overall trading in 2014.

Another short-lived project was the [Yo-mobile](/wiki/Yo-mobile "Yo-mobile"),
a [city car](/wiki/City_car "City car") that could burn both gasoline and
natural gas and was connected to a pair of [electric
motors](/wiki/Electric_motor "Electric motor"). The car was introduced on 13
December 2010 in Moscow, a product of a joint venture between
[Yarovit](/wiki/Yarovit "Yarovit"), a producer of trucks based in [St.
Petersburg, Russia](/wiki/St._Petersburg,_Russia "St. Petersburg, Russia") and
the Onexim investment group, headed by [Mikhail
Prokhorov](/wiki/Mikhail_Prokhorov "Mikhail Prokhorov"), who was the leader
and financier of the project.[73][74] In 2014 the entire project was sold to
the Russian government for a nominal sum, thus signalling the abandonment of
the idea.[75] No actual vehicles other than a few concept cars were ever
produced.

## Economic and political
significance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Automotive_industry_in_Russia&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Economic and political significance")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/AvtoVAZ_administration_building.JPG/220px-
AvtoVAZ_administration_building.JPG)](/wiki/File:AvtoVAZ_administration_building.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:AvtoVAZ_administration_building.JPG "Enlarge")

The main administration building of [Avtovaz](/wiki/Avtovaz "Avtovaz") in
[Togliatti](/wiki/Tolyatti "Tolyatti")

Russia's automotive industry is a significant economic sector. It directly
employs 600,000 people and supports around 2–3 million people in related
industries.[52] It is politically a very important part of the country's
economy: firstly, due to the large number of employed people and secondly,
because many citizens depend on the social services provided by automotive
companies. For example, the well-being of the giant [AvtoVAZ](/wiki/AvtoVAZ
"AvtoVAZ") factory in [Tolyatti](/wiki/Tolyatti "Tolyatti") is massively
important to the city or to the region of [Samara Oblast](/wiki/Samara_Oblast
"Samara Oblast").[76] Tolyatti is a typical [monotown](/wiki/Monotown
"Monotown"), a city whose economy is dependent on a single company. The
factory employed around 100,000 people of the city's population of 700,000 in
2009.[77]

In 2009, former [President](/wiki/President_of_Russia "President of Russia")
[Dmitry Medvedev](/wiki/Dmitry_Medvedev "Dmitry Medvedev") launched the
[Medvedev modernisation programme](/wiki/Medvedev_modernisation_programme
"Medvedev modernisation programme"), which aims to diversify Russia's raw
materials and energy-dominated economy, turning it into a modern high-tech
economy based on innovation. Following this, Russia's automotive industry has
been in the spotlight due to its great potential for modernisation.

Former [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Russia "Prime Minister of
Russia") and current President [Vladimir Putin](/wiki/Vladimir_Putin "Vladimir
Putin") has taken a personal interest in the automotive industry. In a
symbolic gesture of support, Putin made a highly publicized road trip on the
new [Amur Highway](/wiki/Amur_Highway "Amur Highway") in August 2010, driving
2,165 kilometers in a [Lada Kalina](/wiki/Lada_Kalina "Lada Kalina")
Sport.[78] Putin described the car as "excellent, even beyond my
expectations", and praised it as "comfortable" and "almost noise-free."[79]
The event was intended to show support for AvtoVAZ, which was recovering from
the serious economic crisis.[80]

  * Moscow: [Renault Russia](/wiki/Renault_Russia "Renault Russia"),[83] produced 73,633 vehicles in 2015.[87]
  * [Vladivostok](/wiki/Vladivostok "Vladivostok"): [Sollers](/wiki/Sollers "Sollers") (Toyota, Mazda),[83] produced 31,823 vehicles in 2015.[87]
  * [Cherkessk](/wiki/Cherkessk "Cherkessk") \- [Derways](/wiki/Derways "Derways") (Lifan, Geely, Great Wall Hover, Chery),[83] produced 24,800 cars in 2014.[101]
  * [Argun](/wiki/Argun,_Chechen_Republic "Argun, Chechen Republic"): [ChechenAvto](/wiki/ChechenAvto "ChechenAvto") \- produced 6,700 cars in 2016.[102]
  * [Yaroslavl](/wiki/Yaroslavl "Yaroslavl"), [Komatsu Limited](/wiki/Komatsu_Limited "Komatsu Limited") established in 2010, produces rigid dump trucks.
  * [Miass](/wiki/Miass "Miass"), [Iveco](/wiki/Iveco "Iveco") truck plant (Iveco AMT, former joint venture Iveco-[UralAZ](/wiki/UralAZ "UralAZ")) established in 1994. Produces [Iveco Trakker](/wiki/Iveco_Trakker "Iveco Trakker"), [Iveco Stralis](/wiki/Iveco_Stralis "Iveco Stralis").
  * [Uzlovaya](/wiki/Uzlovaya "Uzlovaya"): [Great Wall Motors](/wiki/Great_Wall_Motors "Great Wall Motors") plant under construction.[103]
  * [Esipovo](/w/index.php?title=Esipovo&action=edit&redlink=1 "Esipovo \(page does not exist\)"), Moscow Oblast: [Mercedes-Benz](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz "Mercedes-Benz") plant under construction.[104]
  * [Lipetsk](/wiki/Lipetsk "Lipetsk"): [Lifan](/wiki/Lifan_Group "Lifan Group") plant under construction.[105]

## Manufacturers of automobile
engines[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Automotive_industry_in_Russia&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Manufacturers of automobile engines")]

  * [AvtoVAZ](/wiki/AvtoVAZ "AvtoVAZ"), based in [Togliatti](/wiki/Togliatti_\(city\) "Togliatti \(city\)") and established in 1966. Manufactures gasoline engines for passenger cars under the [Lada](/wiki/Lada "Lada") brand.
  * [Cummins Kama](/wiki/Cummins "Cummins"), based in [Naberezhnye Chelny](/wiki/Naberezhnye_Chelny "Naberezhnye Chelny") and established in 2006 as a joint venture between Cummins and [Kamaz](/wiki/Kamaz "Kamaz"). Manufactures diesel engines for trucks under the Kamaz brand.
  * [Ford Sollers](/wiki/Ford_Sollers "Ford Sollers"), engine plant established in 2015.[106]
  * [Kamaz](/wiki/Kamaz "Kamaz"), based in [Naberezhnye Chelny](/wiki/Naberezhnye_Chelny "Naberezhnye Chelny") and established in 1969. Manufactures diesel engines for heavy-duty trucks and large buses under the brands KAMAZ, [NefAZ](/wiki/Neftekamsk_Automotive_Plant "Neftekamsk Automotive Plant"), and also for the [BTR-80](/wiki/BTR-80 "BTR-80").
  * Tutaev Motor Plant (TMZ), based in [Tutaev](/wiki/Tutaev "Tutaev") and established in 1969. Manufactures diesel engines for heavy trucks under the brands [MZKT](/wiki/MZKT "MZKT") (MZKT-742910), [BAZ](/wiki/Bryansky_Avtomobilny_Zavod "Bryansky Avtomobilny Zavod").
  * [Ulyanovsk Motor Plant](/w/index.php?title=Ulyanovsk_Motor_Plant&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ulyanovsk Motor Plant \(page does not exist\)") (UMZ), based in [Ulyanovsk](/wiki/Ulyanovsk "Ulyanovsk") and established in 1944, part of the [GAZ Group](/wiki/GAZ_Group "GAZ Group"). Manufactures gasoline and gasoline-gas engines for light commercial vehicles and SUVs under the brands [GAZ](/wiki/GAZ "GAZ") ([GAZ Gazelle](/wiki/GAZ_Gazelle "GAZ Gazelle"), [GAZ Sobol](/wiki/GAZ_Sobol "GAZ Sobol")), [UAZ](/wiki/UAZ "UAZ") ([UAZ-3151](/wiki/UAZ-469 "UAZ-469") military performance).
  * [Volkswagen](/wiki/Volkswagen "Volkswagen") Group Rus, plant in [Kaluga](/wiki/Kaluga "Kaluga") producing 1.6 MPI engines.[107]
  * [Yaroslavl Motor Plant](/wiki/Yaroslavl_Motor_Plant "Yaroslavl Motor Plant") (YaMZ), based in [Yaroslavl](/wiki/Yaroslavl "Yaroslavl") and established in 1916 (as Autoworks), 1958 (conversion to the production of engines), part of the [GAZ Group](/wiki/GAZ_Group "GAZ Group"). Manufactures diesel engines for trucks, small buses, large buses, armored vehicles, armored personnel carriers under the brands [UralAZ](/wiki/UralAZ "UralAZ"), [PAZ](/wiki/Pavlovo_Bus_Factory "Pavlovo Bus Factory") ([PAZ-3205](/wiki/PAZ-3205 "PAZ-3205"), [PAZ-4234](/wiki/PAZ-3205 "PAZ-3205")), [LiAZ](/wiki/LiAZ_\(Russia\) "LiAZ \(Russia\)") ([LiAZ-5256](/wiki/LiAZ-5256 "LiAZ-5256")), [BTR-80](/wiki/BTR-80 "BTR-80"), [GAZ Tigr (AMZ Tigr)](/wiki/GAZ_Tigr "GAZ Tigr"), [BAZ](/wiki/Bryansky_Avtomobilny_Zavod "Bryansky Avtomobilny Zavod"), [MAZ](/wiki/Minsk_Automobile_Plant "Minsk Automobile Plant"), [KrAZ](/wiki/KrAZ "KrAZ"), [MZKT](/wiki/MZKT "MZKT"), [BelAZ](/wiki/BelAZ "BelAZ") (younger models with BelAZ-7540-7547 to BelAZ-7547), MoAZ (MoAZ-7505).
  * [Zavolzhye Motor Plant](/wiki/Zavolzhye_Motor_Plant "Zavolzhye Motor Plant") (ZMZ), based in [Zavolzhye](/wiki/Zavolzhye,_Nizhny_Novgorod_Oblast "Zavolzhye, Nizhny Novgorod Oblast") and established in 1958, owned by [UAZ](/wiki/UAZ "UAZ"). Manufactures petrol and diesel engines for off-road vehicles, light commercial vehicles and small buses under the brands [UAZ](/wiki/UAZ "UAZ"), [PAZ](/wiki/Pavlovo_Bus_Factory "Pavlovo Bus Factory") (PAZ-3203, PAZ-3204, [PAZ-3205](/wiki/PAZ-3205 "PAZ-3205")).
  * [ZiL](/wiki/ZiL "ZiL"), based in [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow") and established in 1916. Manufactures gasoline engines for medium trucks under the brands [ZiL](/wiki/ZiL "ZiL") (ZiL-4331).
